newsitem.title: IRAQ: Iraq sees UN consensus against "hijack" of oil deal.
newsitem.headline: Iraq sees UN consensus against "hijack" of oil deal.

text.p: Iraq's Foreign Minister Mohammed Saeed al-Sahaf said he saw a consensus among foreign ministers at a UN General Assembly meeting in New York for a speedy implementation of Baghdad's long-delayed oil-for-food deal.
Sahaf, speaking to Iraqi television on Monday night from New York, said all the ministers he met had called for the $2 billion accord, signed in May, to be carried out soon.
"I noticed quite clearly and unambiguously that there is consensus... (among) the Europeans and others," Sahaf said.

"They are unanimous that implementation of the memorandum of understanding must be speeded up and that the time that was wasted, by countries which are known, was a loss and an unjustified and illegitimate action," he said.
Sahaf did not say which ministers he had met.
"The attempt to hijack the Memorandum of Understanding -- and some of them used this expression -- signed by Iraq and the United Nations is illegitimate," Sahaf added.

Under the plan six years of trade sanctions imposed on Iraq for its 1990 invasion of Kuwait would be eased to allow the export of $2 billion worth of oil over six months. The plan is on hold because of Iraq's military backing of a rebel Kurdish faction over its rivals in the north of the country.

The intervention prompted U.S. missile strikes against Iraqi military installations and warnings that the oil-for-food deal, authorised under U.N. Security Council Resolution 986, would be delayed for months.

The latest delay led the United Nations to appeal for $39.9 million in emergency aid to Iraqi civilians hit by malnutrition and disease. It said clashes in the north "further exacerbated an already dismal humanitarian situation throughout Iraq."

"If you read 986 you won't find any clause in the Memorandum of Understanding which permits a third party to interfere in its implementation," Sahaf said. "Those responsible for its implementation were Iraq and the U.N."

Under the deal $1.13 billion would be earmarked for purchase of food and medical aid. The rest would go towards reparations to individuals, firms and to Kuwait for damage suffered as a result of Iraq's seven-month occupation.
